    Elucidating the Structural Requirement of Uridylpeptide Antibiotics for Antibacterial Activity

    • Yuma Terasawa

    SUBJECTS:
    • Antimicrobial agents,
    • Peptides and proteins,

    • Antibacterial activity
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The synthesis and biological evaluation of analogues of uridylpeptide antibiotics were described, and the molecular interaction between the 3′-hydroxy analogue of mureidomycin A (3′-hydroxymureidomycin A) and its target enzyme, phospho-MurNAc-pentapeptide transferase (MraY), was analyzed in detail. The structure–activity relationship (SAR) involving MraY inhibition suggests that the side chain at the urea-dipeptide moiety does not affect the MraY inhibition. However, the anti-Pseudomonas aeruginosa activity is in great contrast and the urea-dipeptide motif is a key contributor. It is also suggested that the nucleoside peptide permease NppA1A2BCD is responsible for the transport of 3′-hydroxymureidomycin A into the cytoplasm. A systematic SAR analysis of the urea-dipeptide moiety of 3′-hydroxymureidomycin A was further conducted and the antibacterial activity was determined. This study provides a guide for the rational design of analogues based on uridylpeptide antibiotics.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is classified as a Gram-negative bacterium, is a common nosocomial pathogen; healthy individuals are rarely infected by this pathogen because of its low pathogenicity. However, opportunistic and nosocomial infections in newborns and patients with weakened immunity have become problematic. P. aeruginosa also locally infects the urethra, airways, and wounds following medical procedures such as surgery and catheterization, in addition to burns, trauma, and purulent sites; moreover, infection of patients with cystic fibrosis and chronic respiratory diseases by P. aeruginosa can cause increased patient mortality.(1−4) In addition, local infection is followed by systemic infections, such as pneumonia and peritonitis, and it is known that the fatality rate of sepsis due to P. aeruginosa in the blood is as high as 80%. Thus, P. aeruginosa is among pathogens that must be carefully treated because it worsens the prognosis and mortality of patients. Compared to Gram-positive pathogens, P. aeruginosa is inherently less susceptible to antibacterial drugs currently used in the clinic because it possesses an outer membrane that acts as a barrier to prevent their permeation. Furthermore, multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa, which is resistant to all carbapenems, aminoglycosides, and fluoroquinolones used for the treatment of P. aeruginosa infection, has emerged in the clinic. The fatality rate caused by its infection is high because of the very limited number of effective drugs and it is the cause of a severe global health problem. Consequently, development of new drugs for multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa is an urgent task for worldwide health care.(5−7) In choosing novel antibacterial agents, the target must be essential for their growth, and the agent’s mechanism of action should be different from those of existing drugs.(8−12)
    Uridylpeptide antibiotics are nucleoside natural products sharing a common structural feature; a 3′-deoxyuridine with a Z-enamide linkage is attached to a tetrapeptide moiety with a urea linkage reversing the direction of the N- and C-termini, with α,β-diaminobutylic acid playing a pivotal role by connecting the N-terminal amino acid, the urea-dipeptide, and the 3′-deoxyuridine moieties (Figure 1).(13,14) The class includes mureidomycins (MRDs),(15) napsamycins,(16) pacidamycins (PCDs),(17) and sansanmycins.(18) Uridylpeptide antibiotics are a growing class of nucleoside natural products, and their chemical structures vary with various amino acid residues. Among the class of uridylpeptide antibiotics, the MRDs, isolated from Streptomyces flavidoviridens SANK 60486, have been reported to show the most potent antibacterial activity against strains of P. aeruginosa [minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) 1.5–12.5 μg/mL] in vitro and can also protect mice against P. aeruginosa infection.(15b,c) The MRDs and PCDs have been reported to inhibit the formation of lipid II and peptidoglycan and are strong inhibitors of the phospho-MurNAc-pentapeptide transferase (MraY),(19,20) which is responsible for the formation of lipid I in the peptidoglycan biosynthesis pathway.(19−24) As MraY is an essential enzyme in bacteria, it is a potential target for the development of general antibacterial agents.(25) A narrow antibacterial spectrum is characteristic of uridylpeptide antibiotics.(15b,c) They exhibit highly selective antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa but not against other Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacterial pathogens. Different from Gram-positive bacteria, Gram-negative bacteria possess an outer membrane, which acts as a physiological barrier preventing antibacterial drugs from reaching the periplasm. Only limited nutrients and ions necessary for bacterial growth can be incorporated through specific transporters. The observed narrow spectrum of uridylpeptides indicates that they utilize a transporter specifically expressed on P. aeruginosa.(26) We have recently investigated the MraY inhibitory and anti-P. aeruginosa activities of synthetic PCD D and its 3′-hydroxy analogue 1 (3′-hPCD D, Figure 2).(27,28) They exhibited potent MraY inhibitory activity with IC50 values of 22 nM for PCD D and 42 nM for 1 and moderate antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa. The existence of a hydroxyl group at the 3′-position of the uridine moiety does not interfere with either the MraY inhibition or the antibacterial activity. The 3′-hydroxy analogues of uridylpeptide antibiotics are a good starting point to investigate a structure–activity relationship (SAR) of uridylpeptide antibiotics as the 3′-hydroxy analogues are more accessible from a chemical synthesis point of view. Judging from the data reported in the literature, among the uridylpeptide antibiotics shown in Figure 1, those possessing the l-m-tyrosine (l-mTyr) on both N- and C-termini, namely, MRDs, seem to exhibit the strongest antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa. Although SAR studies of antibacterial activity of this class of natural products have independently been conducted,(29−39) the strains tested were not uniform. Therefore, a side-by-side comparison of the impact of each amino acid residue on both MraY inhibition and antibacterial activity must be performed to understand the molecular basis of uridylpeptide antibiotics. Very recently, we reported a complex structure of 3′-hydroxymureidomycin A (3′-hMRD A, 2, Figure 2) bound to MraY from Aquifex aeolicus (MraYAA).(40) Here, we describe the detailed synthesis, biological evaluation, and further SAR of 2. In addition, a transporter responsible for uptake of 2 is also proposed. The aim of this study is to elucidate the structural requirements of 2 for both MraY inhibition and antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa to gain insight into future drug design based on uridylpeptide antibiotics.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis of 3′-hMRD A

    We have previously accomplished the total synthesis of PCD D and 1 featuring a stereoselective construction of the Z-oxy-acyl enamide architecture by copper-catalyzed C–N cross-coupling.(27,28) We have also developed the second-generation synthesis of 1via a Ugi four-component reaction.(38) This second-generation synthesis is a convergent method to provide a range of analogues. However, it also provided an undesired and inactive diastereomer at the 2,3-diaminobutanoic acid residue. Therefore, we developed a more efficient third-generation synthesis to investigate the systematic SAR of uridylpeptide antibiotics. Our retrosynthetic analysis of 2 is shown in Scheme 1. The 2,3-diaminobutanoic acid residue linking to the uridine moiety with a Z-enamide linkage plays a role as a branching scaffold and both the urea-dipeptide and the amino acid are linked to two nitrogen atoms by forming primary and secondary carboxamide linkages. Thereby, 2 was disconnected from these components, 3–5. Thus, a range of analogues suitable for investigating the SAR regarding the urea-dipeptide and the amino acids on both termini could be attained in the last stage of the synthesis. A uridine derivative connected to diaminobutanoic acid via an enamide linkage 3 was disconnected from the 2,3-diaminobutancarboxamide 6 and the Z-vinyl iodide 7 by copper-catalyzed C–N cross-coupling.
    Suitably protected l-mTyr derivatives 5 and 10 were prepared starting from commercially available l-mTyr as shown in Scheme 2. Solution phase synthesis has thus far been used for synthesis of urea-dipeptide; however, it sometimes causes a decrease in the yield of the desired urea-dipeptide because of homodimer formation. Therefore, solid phase synthesis was applied, in which an asymmetric urea-dipeptide can be selectively and easily synthesized by a simple purification procedure (Scheme 3).(41) Fmoc-l-methionine immobilized on the 2-chlorotrityl resin was treated with piperidine, and the resulting amine was converted to the corresponding carbonylimidazolidate, which was reacted with 10 in the presence of i-Pr2NEt to yield urea 12. Finally, removal of the urea-dipeptide from the resin by treatment with 1% TFA in CH2Cl2 cleanly provided 4 with a 78% yield over four steps from 11. This method is suitable for the comprehensive preparation of a variety of urea-dipeptides.
    With 4 and 5 in hand, synthesis of 2 was investigated as shown in Scheme 4. The carboxylic acid 13, which was readily prepared from l-threonine in six steps in large quantity by using a previous procedure,(31) was converted to the carboxamide 14 in 81% yield [NH4Cl, 1-[bis(dimethylamino)methylene]-1H-1,2,3-triazolo[4,5-b]pyridinium 3-oxide hexafluorophosphate (HATU), i-Pr2NEt, dimethylformamide (DMF)]. After cleavage of the N–O bond of 14 by catalytic hydrogenolysis [H2, Pd(OH)2, MeOH], the liberated amine 6 was directly coupled with the iodide 7(27,28) under the conditions using CuI, MeNHCH2CH2NHMe, and Cs2CO3 in tetrahydrofuran (THF) at 70 °C to give the desired Z-enamide 15 in 67% yield. Cross coupling of 7 and 14 also proceeded to produce the corresponding Z-enamide in good yield, however the following N–O bond cleavage was unsuccessful. After protection of the N-methylamine of the carboxamide 6 with an allyloxycarbonyl (Alloc) group, the corresponding N-Alloc carboxamide was used for the coupling. In this case, an unknown byproduct was mainly generated, and the desired 16 was not obtained at all. This problem was solved by simply changing the order of the cross coupling and Alloc protection reactions. After the N-methylamino group of 15 was protected by the Alloc group to give 16 in 93% yield, simultaneous deprotection of the benzyloxymethyl and Boc groups was achieved with BCl3 in CH2Cl2 at −78 °C to afford 3 in 53% yield. The primary amine 3 was condensed with the urea-dipeptide 4 [(2-(1H-benzotriazol-1-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyluronium hexafluorophosphate (HBTU) and i-Pr2NEt in DMF] to give 17 in 84% yield. Removal of the Alloc group at the N-terminus of 17 was conducted by the use of conventional conditions [Pd(PPh3)4, morphorine, THF], and the resulting N-methylamine was condensed with 5 in the presence of HATU and i-Pr2NEt in DMF to afford the fully protected 3′-hMRD A 18 in 44% yield over two steps. Finally, deprotection of the tert-butyldimethylsilyl groups (3HF·Et3N, MeCN) followed by the Boc and t-Bu groups (80% aq. TFA) successfully provided 3′-hMRD A (2) in 45% yield over two steps. During 80% aq. TFA treatment, the methylthio group was oxidized, and the corresponding sulfoxide 19 was also obtained in 35% yield, which was easily separated by reverse-phase column chromatography.

    Biological Activity of 2

    The MraY inhibition of 2 was evaluated with fluorescence-based MraY inhibitory assay(42) using the purified MraY enzyme (Staphylococcus aureus, MraYSA) and dansylated Park’s nucleotide that was prepared by dansylation of Park’s nucleotide chemically synthesized with our method.(43) The data were obtained from three independent experiments. As shown in Figure 3 and Table 1, 2 exhibits a strong MraYSA inhibitory activity, with an IC50 value of 1.3 ± 0.2 nM and is 34-fold more potent than 1. The antibacterial activity of 2 against a range of P. aeruginosa strains, including a variety of clinical isolates and serotypes, was then investigated. The data were obtained from three independent experiments, and MIC values for each compound are within 4-fold, which are described as a range of these values. 3′-Hydroxymureidomycin A (2) exhibits a potent antibacterial activity over a wide range of P. aeruginosa strains with MIC values ranging from 4 to 128 μg/mL, which are lower than those of 1. It is noteworthy that 2 is effective against multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa (MDRP62) with an MIC value of 16–32 μg/mL. Improvement of the MraYSA inhibitory activity of 2 over 1 is correlated with the anti-P. aeruginosa activity, and it was revealed that 2 possesses superior properties in terms of both MraYSA inhibitory activity and anti-P. aeruginosa activity. Overall, the replacement of amino acid resides at both C- and N-termini with l-mTyrs improved the biological activity, confirming 2 as a superior candidate, as expected from the literature review.(13−20) Selective toxicity is an important issue in chemotherapy for infectious disease. Accordingly, the cytotoxicity of 2 against human hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) cells was then evaluated. Tunicamycins were also tested as a positive control and showed evidence of cytotoxicity, with an IC50 of 38.6 μM. Under these conditions, 2 exhibited no cytotoxicity (IC50 > 100 μM). This result indicates that 2 showed selective toxicity against bacterial strains. The observed high therapeutic index is a desirable property for antibacterial agents. Thus, 2 was confirmed to be a selective anti-P. aeruginosa agent.
    Table 1. Biological Activity of 1 and 2c
      12
    IC50 for MraYSA (nM)a 44 ± 41.3 ± 0.2

    a

    The inhibitory activities of the compounds against purified MraYSA were determined in a manner similar to the experiments shown in Figure 3.

    b

    HepG2 cells were seeded in 96-well tissue culture plates at 1 × 105 cells/well. After 24 h, the cells were treated with varying concentrations of compounds for 24 h. After the treatment, the cell viability was measured by WST-8 assay. In these experiments, tunicamycin exhibited cytotoxicity with the IC50 value of 38.6 μM.

    c

    MICs were determined by a microdilution broth method as recommended by the CLSI. The data were obtained from three independent experiments described as a range of values.

    Elucidating the Interaction between MraY and 2

    The X-ray crystal structure of a complex of muraymycin D2 (MRY D2), other class of nucleoside natural products and a strong MraY inhibitor, bound to MraYAA has been elucidated (PDB code 5CKR, 2.95 Å).(44) It is also revealed that MraYAA undergoes a large conformational change upon binding to MRY D2 by comparing the structure with the apoMraYAA structure (PDB code 4J72) (Figure 4b,d,f).(45) With 2 possessing better properties, the X-ray crystal structure of a complex of 2 bound to MraYAA (PDB code 6OZ6, 3.832–3.70 Å) was solved by our collaborative study to understand the molecular basis of the interaction of 2 and MraYAA (Figure 4a,c,e).(40) The complex of 2 bound to MraYAA is similar to that of MRY D2. Using the alignment of the sequence of MraYSA and MraY from P. aeruginosa (MraYPA) (Figure 5, for larger image, see the Supporting Information) on the crystal structure of MraYAA bound to 2 as a template, in this study, we developed homology models of MraYSA and MraYPA (Figure 6) using the SWISS-MODEL(46) to predict the molecular basis of 2 interacting with MraYSA, which is used for enzymatic assays, and MraYPA expressed in P. aeruginosa, the target bacteria. These models reveal that overall, the three-dimensional structures of the MraYSA and MraYPA models are quite similar to that of MraYAA, and the amino acid residues and their interacting modes are almost identical among MraYAA, MraYSA, and MraYPA (Figures 4a, 6a,b). Conserved residues in Loop C of the cytoplasmic faces of both MraYSA and MraYPA form a hydrogen-bonding network around the uracil moiety of 2, which is further stabilized by a π–π stacking interaction with Phe226 in MraYSA and Phe264 in MraYPA (Figure 6a,b). A similar interaction with Phe262 was observed in the MraYAA/MRY D2 complex (Figure 4b). The N-terminal l-mTyr residue of 2 interacts with the conserved residues Thr49 in MraYSA, Thr73 in MraYPA (Thr75 in MraYAA), and Asn172 in MraYSA and Asn195 in MraYPA (Asn190 in MraYAA), which create a shallow pocket adjacent to the uracil binding pocket (Figure 6c,d). In the MraYAA/MRY D2 complex, this interaction is formed by the 5′-aminoribose moiety (Figure 4d). In detail, the amino group at the l-mTyr residue of 2 forms a hydrogen bond with Asp229 in MraYSA and Asp267 in MraYPA (Asp265 in MraYAA), among the most conserved and essential residues in the enzymatic activity of MraY. Of note is the interaction of the hydroxy group at the l-mTyr residue. The hydroxy group interacts with Thr49 in MraYSA and Thr73 in MraYPA (Thr75 in MraYAA) as in the hydroxy group at the aminoribose moiety of MRY D2. 3′-Hydroxypacidamycin 1 has an l-alanine residue at the corresponding site, which lacks the hydroxy group. This structural analysis revealed the reason for the improved MraYSA inhibitory activity of 2 over 1. Observations that the 5′-amino-4′,5′-didehydro-5′-deoxyribofuranose moiety does not directly interact with MraY and the 3′-hydroxy group of 2 is exposed to a solvent-accessible area are in good accordance with our previous results where existence of the hydroxyl group at the 3′-position of the uridine moiety of 1 does not interfere with MraY inhibition.(28)
    3′-hMRD A (2) and MRY D2 share a urea-dipeptide moiety in their chemical structure though the amino acid residues constituting the urea-dipeptide moiety are different between 2 and MRY D2. The moieties of each extend toward transmembrane (TM) 9b and Loop E, forming an interaction with the essential residue His288 in MraYSA and His326 in MraYPA (His324 in MraYAA) in the Loop E helix (Figure 6e,f). One of the two hydrogens in the urea-motif of 2 forms a hydrogen bond with the carbonyl oxygen of the Ala321 in the MraYAA crystal structure (Figure 4f). However, both hydrogens in the urea-motif of 2 are suggested to form hydrogen bonds with the carbonyl oxygen of the Ser284 in the MraYSA model and the Ala322 in the MraYPA model upon minimization of the complex structures (Figure 6e,f). In all cases, the carboxylate in the C-terminus of 2 interacts with Gln269 in MraYSA and Gln307 in MraYPA (Gln305 in MraYAA). Contrary to the interaction observed for the urea-motif of 2 and MRY D2, none of the side chains in the urea-dipeptide moiety interacts with any MraY (Figures 4e,f and 6e,f). Our previous SAR study of MRY D2 regarding the urea-dipeptide moiety indicated that the observed interaction between the urea-dipeptide moiety and TM9b and Loop E is not necessary for MraYSA inhibition.(47,48) Namely, truncation of the urea-dipeptide moiety of the lipophilic analogue 20, which is a membrane-permeable analogue of MRY D2, did not diminish the inhibitory activity at all and the truncated analogue 21 still showed a potent MraY inhibitory activity comparable to that of MRY D2 and 20 (Figure 7). It is suggested that the binding affinity of MRYs is mainly contributed by the aminoribosyluridine moiety, which is superimposable to the uridine and l-mTyr moieties in 2, and the urea-dipeptide moiety plays a role as an accessory motif. To see the impact of the urea-peptide moiety in the case of 2, several truncated analogues 22–24 (Figure 8), which lack the urea-motif, were synthesized (Schemes S1 and S2), and their MraYSA inhibitory activity was evaluated (Table 2). As a result, truncation of the urea-motif of 2 led to a complete loss of inhibitory activity, in great contrast to the results observed for MRYSA. These results clearly indicate that the urea-dipeptide motif is also a key contributor in 2, in addition to the uridine and l-mTyr moieties. The fact that 23 has a carboxamide functionality with only one hydrogen suggests that both hydrogens in the urea-motif likely form hydrogen bonds with the carbonyl oxygen of the Ser284 in the MraYSA and the Ala322 in the MraYPA, as predicted by modeling (Figure 6). However, it is also true that only the C-terminal carboxylic acid moiety could be important for MraY inhibition. Such kinds of analogues have never been tested and the possibility remains to be elucidated. Brandish et al., through kinetic analysis of the enzymatic reaction, revealed that MRD A inhibits the function of MraY in a concentration- and time-dependent manner and thus is a slow-binding inhibitor.(49) Initially, this was proposed to be a reaction with an unusual enamide functional group although the enamide was later found not to be an essential pharmacophore.(50) Presumably, the urea-dipeptide motif, uridine and l-mTyr moieties cooperatively interact with MraY during the course of the conformational change, allowing the urea-dipeptide moiety of 2 to bind to the side of TM9b and Loop E to form a more stable conformation, although more detailed analyses will be necessary to support this hypothesis.
    Table 2. Biological Activity of Analogues
     19222324
    IC50 (nM)a4.7>1000>1000>1000
    MIC (μg/mL)b32n.a.n.a.n.a.
    a

    The inhibitory activities of the compounds against purified MraYSA were determined in a manner similar to the experiments shown in Figure 3.

    b

    MICs for P. aeruginosa were determined by a microdilution broth method as recommended by the CLSI. n.a.: not analyzed.

    Identification of the Protein Associated with 3′-hMRD A Resistance

    Our initial SAR study with 1, 2, and 22–24 suggests that their amino acid composition has a great impact on antibacterial activity. The active site of MraY faces the cytoplasm and these inhibitors must be incorporated into the cytoplasm to reach the active site. It is unlikely that they pass through the outer and inner membranes by passive diffusion, considering the hydrophilic chemical structures of uridylpeptide antibiotics and the analogues investigated in this study. In conjunction with the narrow spectrum of uridylpeptide antibiotics, it is suggested that they utilize a transporter specifically expressed on P. aeruginosa; therefore, it is very important to understand how they are taken up by P. aeruginosa. It is known that both Escherichia coli and P. aeruginosa show intrinsic resistance to uridylpeptide antibiotics. Gotoh et al. reported that the resistance of E. coli to MRDs A and C is attributed to efflux by extrusion via the AcrAB-TolC pump.(51) Recently, Mistry et al. and Pletzer et al. independently found that the resistance of P. aeruginosa to PCD 4 and D is primarily due to a loss of function of uptake into the cell mediated by peptide ABC transporters belonging to the nucleoside peptide permease (Npp) family, NppA1A2BCD, which is encoded in the P. aeruginosa genome and was previously designated the oligopeptide transport system.(26) The latter reports are in good accordance with the selective antibacterial activity of uridylpeptide antibiotics only against P. aeruginosa. Considering these reports, it is presumed that the transporter recognizes chemical structures and/or sequence compositions of the amino acid residues involved in uridylpeptide antibiotics. We briefly investigated whether the synthetic analogue 2, which possesses the extra hydroxy group at the 3′-position of the parent MRD A, behaves similarly. Exposure of P. aeruginosa PAO1 to 2 resulted in emergence of resistant mutants with an 8-fold increase of the MIC values within a day. Among 30 resistant mutants obtained in this study, and the full genome sequences of the three mutants, MRD1, 2, and 30 were determined by next-generation genome sequencing, and the sequences obtained were compared with those of wild-type P. aeruginosa PAO1 (Table 3). Several nucleotide mutations were found in the genes encoding NppA1A2BCD (PA1810) as reported previously, and five nucleotide insertions attributed to functional disruption of NppA1A2BCD were commonly detected in MRD1, 2, and 30. These results support previous reports(26) that NppA1A2BCD is responsible for transport of 2 into the cytoplasm. To confirm whether the NppA1A2BC transporter of P. aeruginosa PAO1 is truly required for uptake of 2 across the inner membrane, antimicrobial susceptibility of two transposonmutants P. aeruginosa PW4182 and PW4181 (Table 4), which have functional disruptions of NppA1A2BCD via transposon insertion into the encoding gene, was investigated. As expected, two mutants were totally resistant to 2 (MIC > 128 μg/mL), and therefore, the NppA1A2BCD transporter is responsible for uptake of 2 in P. aeruginosa PAO1. As NppA1A2BCD transports peptides, the observed difference in the antibacterial activity of analogues synthesized in this study (Table 2) may be attributed to the mode of recognition of the amino acid sequence of analogues by NppA1A2BCD.
    Table 3. Properties of P. aeruginosa Mutants Resistant to 2

    Table 4. Properties of Transposonmutants P. aeruginosa Mutants

    Detailed SAR Regarding the Urea-Dipeptide Moiety

    Uridylpeptide antibiotics have a dual nature as antibacterial agents: they must be a substrate of a transporter, one of the candidates of which is suggested to be NppA1A2BCD, as well as an inhibitor of MraY. Therefore, it has proved difficult to design analogues of these antibiotics that retain both MraY inhibition and antimicrobial activity.(52) NppA1A2BCD transports peptides with a certain selectivity for the length and sequence; however, the details of the selectivity and sequence preference remain unclear.(26) It was revealed that the l-mTyr at the N-terminus of 2 largely contributes to MraY inhibition and none of the side chains in the urea-dipeptide moiety of 2 interacts with MraYAA in the X-ray crystal structure or with MraYSA and MraYPA constructed by homology modeling. These results prompted us to see the impact of the side chains on MraY inhibition and antibacterial activity through a systematic SAR of the urea-dipeptide moiety. In a different study, Bugg et al. proposed a structural link between two aromatic residues (l-Trp or l-mTyr at the C-terminus and l-mTyr at the N-terminus) in the MDR/PCD structures, and an Arg-Trp-x-x-Trp motif on the lysis protein E of bacteriophage ϕX174,(53) which inhibits MraY via a protein–protein interaction remote from the active site(55) and suggested that two aromatic residues in the MDR/PCD are important for uptake into the cell via a hydrophobic channel present in the structure of MraY. Therefore, the impact of the internal amino acid residue at the urea-dipeptide moiety on antibacterial activity was investigated as the index of NppA1A2BCD transport by using a set of analogues 25a–t. l-Tryptophan was chosen for the C-terminal amino acid instead of l-mTyr (Figure 9). These analogues were prepared by a modified synthetic route for 2. Namely, l-mTyr at the N-terminus was introduced to 15 to give 27 prior to connecting the urea-dipeptide moiety 29a–t to reduce the synthetic steps (Scheme 5). The attempt to prepare a free primary amine obtained by deprotection of 27 by BCl3 failed because the free amine underwent decomposition, resulting in removal of the Fmoc group at the N-terminus. Therefore, the free amine was converted to the corresponding hydrochloride salt 28, which is stable and can be stored, immediately after deprotection of the protecting groups. Except for 29t, solid-phase parallel synthesis of urea-dipeptides is suitable for rapid access to the urea-dipeptide carboxylic acids 29a–s. Condensation of 28 and 29a–t followed by deprotection afforded 25a–t.
    The IC50 values for the MraYSA inhibitory activities of 25a–s were essentially within a similar range (0.22 ± 0.07 to 7.6 ± 1.6 nM (Table 5)) and a variety of amino acid residues with various physicochemical properties including negative or positive charges are acceptable for MraY inhibition. Analogues 1 and 25b share the same urea-dipeptide moiety, with a structural difference of a single amino acid replacement at the N-terminus (l-Ala vsl-mTyr). The fact that this replacement resulted in a significant, 32-fold, increase in MraYSA inhibition supported the hypothesis that the l-mTyr at the N-terminus largely contributes to the inhibitory activity, as was expected in the interactions in a uridine-adjacent pocket (Figure 5c,d). Analogues possessing aromatic residues tend to exhibit a stronger inhibitory activity among 25a–s, and the l-Tyr analogue 25i showed the strongest MraYSA inhibitory activity with an IC50 value of 0.22 ± 0.07 nM. One exception is the l-Pro analogue 25t, which largely decreased the inhibitory activity with an IC50 value of >500 nM. Replacement with l-Pro consequently results in a deficit of one of the two hydrogens in the urea-motif, and the decrease in inhibitory activity of 25t is consistent with the SAR for the truncated analogues 22–24. Overall, the SAR of 25a–t regarding MraY inhibition is in good accordance with the structural features observed for the X-ray crystal structure of the complex of 2 bound to MraYAA. The antibacterial activities of analogues against P. aeruginosa PAO1, which may reflect the selectivity for their cellular uptake by NppA1A2BCD, were next investigated. Different from MraYSA inhibitory activity, it was found that the side chains in the urea-dipeptide largely affected the antibacterial activity. Except for the l-Leu analogue 25c, analogues possessing hydrophobic residues such as l-Ile, l-Val, and l-Met (25d, 25e, 25g, respectively) and aromatic residues such as l-Phe, l-Tyr, and l-Trp (25h, 25i, and 25j, respectively) exhibited a comparable antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa PAO1 to 2 with MICs ranging from 16 to 128 μg/mL. The l-Val analogue is the best in terms of antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa among those tested in this study (MIC 16 μg/mL for 25e). Analogues containing less hydrophobic residues such as l-Gly (25a), charged residues, such l-Asp, l-Glu, l-Lys, and l-Arg (25l, 25m, 25n, and 25o, respectively), and polar residues such as l-His, l-Ser, l-Asn, and l-Gln (25k, 25p, 25r, and 25s, respectively), which can form a hydrogen bonding, decreased the antibacterial activity to a large extent. These results suggest that polar amino acid residues at the internal amino acid residue of the urea-dipeptide moiety are not preferred but hydrophobic residues are preferred for incorporation. Of interest is the antibacterial activity of 25d, 25e, and 25q. Namely, the analogues containing β-branched amino acid residues such as l-Ile, l-Val, and l-Thr tend to exhibit better antibacterial activity.
    Table 5. Biological Activity of Analogues 25a–ta,b

    a

    The inhibitory activities of the compounds against purified MraYSA were determined in a manner similar to the experiments shown in Figure 3.

    b

    MICs for P. aeruginosa were determined by a microdilution broth method as recommended by the CLSI. The data were obtained from three independent experiments described as a range of the values.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Development of a novel lead effective against multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa is urgently needed worldwide. Intrigued by the specific antibacterial activity and potent MraY inhibitory activity of uridylpeptide antibiotics, the SAR of the 3′-hydroxy derivative of mureidomycin A (2) was conducted to elucidate its structural requirement for both MraY inhibition and antibacterial activities against P. aeruginosa. First, a synthetic method capable of providing a range of analogues suitable for investigating the SAR was established as the third-generation synthesis, where the urea-dipeptide moiety and N-terminal amino acid are introduced in the last stage of the synthesis. Design and synthesis of analogues guided by X-ray crystal structure analysis of 2 bound to MraYAA was conducted to elucidate the mode of MraY inhibition. The SAR of analogues 25a–t suggests that hydrophobic residues at the internal amino acid residue of the urea-dipeptide moiety are a better substrate for bacterial incorporation. It was suggested that the interaction of the urea-motif is essential for the strong MraY inhibitory activity and that the amino acid residues in the motif did not contribute to the inhibition. The SAR regarding anti-P. aeruginosa activity is in great contrast to that for MraY inhibition, as anti-P. aeruginosa activity is greatly affected by the amino acid residues. As shown in this study, a side-by-side comparison of the impact of each amino acid residue on both MraY inhibition and antibacterial activity enabled us to evaluate a more reliable SAR of uridylpeptide antibiotics and their analogues. A summary of the SAR of uridylpeptide antibiotics revealed by this study includes the following: (1) l-mTyr at the N-terminus is favored to increase the MraY inhibitory activity, (2) the interaction of the urea-dipeptide motif is indispensable for the MraY inhibitory activity, (3) the side chain at the urea-dipeptide moiety does not affect the MraY inhibition, and (4) the antibacterial activity of uridylpeptide antibiotics depends on their amino acid composition, presumably because of the selectivity for cellular uptake by NppA1A2BCD. As for antibacterial activity, analogues possessing hydrophobic residues and aromatic residues exhibited a comparable antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa PAO1 to 2. There are parallel trends between these data and those reported in previous studies.(33,39) With this SAR information in hand, future optimization of the amino acid residues would improve the antibacterial activity against P. aeruginosa. Thus, it will be necessary to understand the structural requirements of uridylpeptide antibiotics in NppA1A2BCD recognition in much more detail with future SAR analyses. Uridylpeptide antibiotics have a dual nature as an antibacterial agent and it is challenging to design analogues that retain both MraY inhibition and antimicrobial activity. This study provides a guide for the rational design of analogues based on uridylpeptide antibiotics.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Experimental Methods

    NMR spectra were reported in parts per million (δ) relative to tetramethylsilane (0.00 ppm) as the internal standard unless otherwise noted. Coupling constant (J) was reported in hertz (Hz). Abbreviations of multiplicity were as follows: s: singlet, d; doublet, t: triplet, q: quartet, m: multiplet, br: broad. Data were presented as follows; chemical shift (multiplicity, integration, coupling constant). Assignment was based on 1H–1H COSY, HMBC, and HMQC NMR spectra. Purity of all the compounds tested for biological evaluation was confirmed to be >95% by liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS) analysis as shown in the Supporting Information.

    (S)-2-[(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino]-3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)propanoic Acid (5)

    A mixture of H-l-mTyr-OH (8) (1.50 g, 8.28 mmol) and NaHCO3 (1.04 g, 12.4 mmol) in THF (40 mL) and H2O (40 mL) was treated with Boc2O (1.99 g, 9.11 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 17 h. The mixture was partitioned between AcOEt and 1 M aq HCl. The organic phase was washed with brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford a crude carboxylic acid. A solution of the crude carboxylic acid and imidazole (3.38 g, 49.7 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (83 mL) was treated with TIPSCl (5.26 mL, 24.8 mmol) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 44 h. The mixture was partitioned between AcOEt and 1 M aq HCl, and the organic phase was washed with water and brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. A solution of the residue in THF/MeOH (2/1, 83 mL) and H2O (13 mL) was treated with K2CO3 (1.60 g, 11.6 mmol) at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was partitioned between AcOEt and 1 M aq HCl, and the organic phase was washed with water and brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (50% AcOEt/hexane) to afford 5 (3.30 g, 7.54 mmol, 91%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 7.15 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 7.7 Hz), 6.80–6.68 (m, 3H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-6-mTyr), 4.89 (br d, 1H, NH-mTyr, JNH-mTyr,α-mTyr = 7.4 Hz), 4.57 (m, 1H, H-α-mTyr), 3.12 (dd, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 4.6, Jgem = 13.7 Hz), 3.03 (dd, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 6.3, Jgem = 13.7 Hz), 1.42 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.24 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.10 (s, 12H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.08 (s, 6H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ 176.8, 156.3, 137.3, 129.7, 122.1, 121.2, 118.8, 80.4, 54.3, 37.6, 28.4, 18.1, 12.8; ESIMS-LR m/z: 438 [(M + H)+]; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C23H39NO5SiNa, 460.2490; found, 460.2503; [α]D24 +13.7 (c 0.44, MeOH).

    tert-Butyl (S)-2-[(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino]-3-{3-[(triisopropylsilyl)oxy]phenyl}-propanoate (9)

    A solution of 5 (2.51 g, 5.74 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (57 mL) was treated with O-tert-butyl 2,2,2-trichloroacetimidate (5.14 mL, 28.7 mmol) at room temperature. The mixture was then warmed to 45 °C and stirred for 2 h. Additional O-tert-butyl 2,2,2-trichloroacetimidate (5.14 mL, 28.7 mmol) was added to the mixture, which was stirred for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (3% AcOEt/hexane) to afford 9 (2.70 g, 5.47 mmol, 95%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 7.11 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 8.0 Hz), 6.75–6.70 (m, 3H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-6-mTyr), 4.96 (br d, 1H, NH-mTyr, JNH-mTyr,α-mTyr = 8.2 Hz), 4.43 (dd, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,NH = 8.2, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 6.0 Hz), 3.00 (d, 2H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 6.0 Hz), 1.42 (s, 9H, Boc-tBu), 1.41 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.29–1.19 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.10 (d, 18H, J = 6.9 Hz, H-Si[CH(CH3)2]3); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ 171.0, 156.1, 155.2, 137.8, 129.3, 122.4, 121.4, 118.3, 82.1, 79.7, 54.8, 38.3, 28.5, 28.1, 18.1, 12.8; ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C27H48NO5Si, 494.33; found, 494.00.

    tert-Butyl (S)-2-Amino-3-[3-(triisopropylsilyloxy)phenyl]propanoate Trifluoro Acetate Salt (10)

    Compound 9 (2.60 g, 5.27 mmol) was treated with 10% TFA/CH2Cl2 (53 mL) at room temperature for 1.5 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (3% MeOH/CHCl3 containing 0.1% TFA) to afford 10 (2.60 g, 5.30 mmol, 97%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 400 MHz): δ 7.24 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 7.8 Hz), 6.88–6.80 (m, 3H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-6-mTyr), 4.12 (dd, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 7.8, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 6.9 Hz), 3.11 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.42 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.29 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.13 (s, 12H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.11 (s, 6H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C22H40NO3Si, 394.28; found, 394.0.

    (S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-1-oxo-3-{[3-(triisopropylsilyloxy)phenyl]propan-2-yl-carbamoyl}-l-methionine (4)

    2-Chlorotrityl chloride resin (1.6 mmol/g, 200 mg) was placed in a 10 mL polypropylene syringe fitted with a polyethylene filter disc. The resin was washed with CH2Cl2 (2 mL), and a solution of Fmoc-Met-OH (356 mg, 960 μmol) and iPr2NEt (334 μL, 1.92 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was then added. After the mixture was agitated at room temperature for 3 h, the solvent and reagents were removed by suction. The resin was subjected to the following washing treatments with CH2Cl2/MeOH/iPr2NEt (17/2/1, 2 mL × 3), DMF (2 mL × 2), and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 2). The resin was treated with piperidine/DMF (1/4, 5 min, then 1/9, 15 min) to remove the Fmoc group at room temperature and washed with DMF (2 mL × 3) and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). A solution of 1,1′-carbonyldiimidazole (156 mg, 960 μmol) and N-methylmorpholine (211 mg, 1.92 μmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added to each resin. After the mixture was agitated at room temperature for 1 min, the solvent and reagents were removed by suction. This procedure was repeated 5 times. The resin was washed with CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). Then, a solution of 10 (189 mg, 480 μmol) and iPr2NEt (167 μL, 960 μmol) in DMF (2 mL) was added to the resins. The mixture was agitated at room temperature for 3 h, and the solvent and reagents were removed by suction. The resin was washed with DMF (2 mL × 3) and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). The resin was treated with 1% TFA/CH2Cl2 to cleave the urea-dipeptide from the resin, and the filtrate was partitioned between AcOEt and H2O. The organic phase was washed with brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford 4 (141 mg, 248 μmol, 78%) as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 400 MHz): δ 7.14 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 7.9 Hz), 6.82 (d, 1H, H-6-mTyr, J6-mTyr,5-mTyr = 7.9 Hz), 6.76–6.73 (m, 2H, H-4-mTyr, H-2-mTyr), 4.42–4.38 (m, 2H, H-α-mTyr, H-α-Met), 2.95 (d, 2H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 6.8 Hz), 2.56–2.52 (m, 2H, H-γ-Met), 2.12–2.08 (m, 1H, H-β-Met), 2.08 (s, 3H, SCH3), 1.94–1.84 (m, 1H, H-β-Met), 1.40 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.28–1.19 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.11 (d, 18H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, J = 7.3 Hz); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 100 MHz): δ 176.8, 173.1, 159.7, 157.3, 139.7, 130.3, 123.6, 122.1, 119.1, 82.8, 56.2, 53.2, 39.3, 33.4, 31.0, 28.3, 18.4, 15.3, 13.9; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C28H49N2O6SSi2, 569.3075; found, 569.3064.

    (2S,3S)-2-[(tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino]-3-[(N-benzyloxy-N-methyl)amino]-butanamide (14)

    A mixture of (2S,3S)-2-[(tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino]-3-[(N-benzyloxy-N-methyl)amino]butanoic acid (13, 7.6 g, 22.3 mmol), NH4Cl (11.9 g, 223 mmol), HATU (11.0 g, 29.0 mmol), and N-methylmorpholine (31.9 mL, 290 mmol) in DMF (220 mL) was stirred at 0 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with H2O and extracted with AcOEt. The combined organic layers were washed with 0.2 M aq HCl and brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was crystallized from AcOEt to afford 14 (6.1 g, 18.1 mmol, 81%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 400 MHz): δ 7.38–7.26 (m, 5H, OCH2C6H5), 4.66 (d, 1H, OCH2Ph, Jgem = 10.7 Hz), 4.63 (d, 1H, OCH2Ph, Jgem = 10.7 Hz), 4.49 (br s, 1H, H-α), 3.16 (qd, 1H, H-β, Jβ,γ = Jβ,α = 6.8 Hz), 2.61 (s, 3H, H-NCH3), 1.46 (s, 9H, Boc), 1.07 (d, H-γ, Jγ,β = 6.8 Hz); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 100 MHz): δ 176.8, 158.0, 138.6, 130.1, 129.3, 128.9, 80.8, 75.6, 64.4, 57.6, 42.3, 28.7, 11.1; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C17H28N3O4, 338.2074; found, 338.2078; [α]D25 −8.5 (c 0.87, MeOH).

    Compound 15

    A mixture of 14 (2.55 g, 6.78 mmol) and Pd(OH)2 (1.1 g) in MeOH (68 mL) was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 3 h under H2 atmosphere. The catalyst was filtered off through a Celite pad, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to afford a crude carboxamide. The crude carboxamide, 7 (4.75 g, 6.78 mmol), CuI (1.25 g, 8.14 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (13.1 g, 10.2 mmol) were added to a flask. Dried THF (68 mL) and N,N-dimethyl-1,2-ethylendiamine (2.8 mL, 16.3 mmol) were added to the mixture, which was heated at 70 °C for 7 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with AcOEt, the insoluble substances were filtered off through a Celite pad, and the filtrate was washed with H2O and brine, dried (Na2SO4), and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (CHCl3/MeOH = 6–10%) to afford 15 (3.65 g, 4.53 mmol, 67%) as a white foam. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 9.15 (br s, 1H, NH), 7.38–7.27 (m, 5H, NCH2OCH2C6H5), 7.17 (d, 1H, H-6-uridine, J6,5 = 8.2 Hz), 6.30 (s, 1H, H-5′-uracil), 6.29 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 6.0 Hz), 5.86 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.2 Hz), 5.50 (d, 2H, NCH2OBn, Jgem = 6.4 Hz), 4.69 (s, 2H, NCH2OCH2Ph), 4.40 (d, 1H, H-3′-uridine, JH-3′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 4.1 Hz), 4.17 (dd, 1H, H-2′-uridine, JH-2′-uridine,H-1′-uridine = 6.0, JH-2′-uridine,H-3′-uridine = 4.1 Hz), 4.05 (dd, 1H, H-α-DABA, JH-α-DABA,H-β-DABA = 6.9 Hz), 2.74 (dq, 1H, H-β-DABA, JH-β-DABA,H-α-DABA = 6.9, JH-β-DABA,H-γ-DABA = 6.4 Hz), 2.38 (s, 3H, NCH3), 1.41 (s, 9H, Boc-tBu), 1.13 (d, 3H, H-γ-DABA, JH-γ-DABA,H-β-DABA = 6.4 Hz), 0.90 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.83 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.11 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.09 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.03 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.03 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ 168.4, 162.4, 156.5, 151.2, 141.4, 138.3, 137.8, 128.4, 127.8, 103.2, 100.9, 89.6, 75.8, 72.2, 71.2, 70.5, 33.8, 28.4, 25.9, 25.7, 18.3, 18.0, 16.2, −4.1, −4.4, −4.9; ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C39H66N5O9Si2, 804.44; found, 805.0; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C39H66N5O9Si2, 804.4394; found, 804.4399; [α]D19 −28.1 (c 0.75, CHCl3).

    Compound 16

    A mixture of 15 (2.62 g, 3.25 mmol) and AllocCl (414.8 μmol, 3.90 mmol) in THF/sat. aq NaHCO3 (1/1, 40 mL) was vigorously stirred at 0 °C for 5 h. The reaction was quenched with MeOH, and the organic solvents were removed under reduced pressure. The resulting aqueous phase was extracted with AcOEt, which was washed with H2O and brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (ϕ 5 × 10 cm, hexane/AcOEt = 10–30%) to afford 16 (2.7 mg, 3.0 μmol, 92%) as a white foam. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz, 1:1 mixture of rotamers): δ 7.70 (d, 1H, H-6-uridine, JH-6-uridine,H-5-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 7.68 (d, 1H, H-6-uridine, JH-6-uridine,H-5-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 7.33–7.28 (m, 5H, NCH2OCH2C6H5), 6.40 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 6.3 Hz), 6.35 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 6.9 Hz), 6.25 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 5.97–5.88 (m, 2H, H-5-uridine, CH-Alloc), 5.48 (s, 5H, CH2OBn), 5.31, 5.29 (each d, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 17.2, 16.6 Hz), 5.18 (d, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 10.3 Hz), 4.65 (s, 2H, NCH2OCH2Ph), 4.58–4.51 (m, 4H, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine, CH2-Alloc), 4.44–4.28 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 4.37 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 2.81 (s, 3H, NCH3), 1.42 (s, 9H, Boc-tBu), 1.21 (m, 3H, H-γ-DABA), 0.94 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.85 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.17 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.14 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.08 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.02 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 125 MHz, 1:1 mixture of rotamers): δ 169.7, 164.2, 157.6, 152.8, 144.0, 141.4, 141.2, 139.1, 134.2, 129.3, 128.8, 128.7, 117.9, 117.6, 1103.7, 103.5, 101.4, 101.3, 91.0, 90.3, 81.0, 76.5, 76.1, 73.0, 72.7, 71.5, 67.6, 67.3, 58.4, 54.5, 30.4, 28.7, 26.4, 26.2, 19.1, 18.8, 15.2, 14.3, −3.9. −4.2, −4.3, −4.8; ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C43H70N5O11Si2, 888.46; found, 888.4; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C43H70N5O11Si2, 888.4605; found, 888.4598; [α]D24 −0.65 (c 1.06, CHCl3).

    Compound 17

    A solution of 16 (444 mg, 500 μmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) was treated with 1 M BCl3 in CH2Cl2 (5 mL, 5 mmol) at −78 °C for 30 min and then at 0 °C for 15 min. After sat. aq NaHCO3 was added to the mixture, the resulting biphasic mixture was vigorously stirred for 15 min. The mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2, which was washed with sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine. The organic layer was dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was semipurified by silica gel column chromatography (ϕ 2 × 10 cm, CHCl3/MeOH = 0–1–2–5%) to afford amine (177.9 mg, 266.3 μmol, 53%) as a white foam. This amine was immediately used in the next reaction. A mixture of the amine (47.3 mg, 70.7 μmol), urea-dipeptide 4 (60.4 mg, 106.1 μmol), HOBt (14.3 mg, 106.1 μmol), and iPr2NEt (37.0 μL, 212.2 μmol) in CH2Cl2 (1 mL) was treated with EDCI (20.4 mg, 106.1 mmol) at room temperature for 12 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with AcOEt and washed with 0.1 M aq HCl, sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine. The organic layer was dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography (ϕ 1.5 × 10 cm, CHCl3/MeOH = 0–1–2%) to afford 17 (64.2 mg, 53 μmol, 75%) as a colorless amorphous solid. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz, 1:1 mixture of rotamers): δ 7.68, 7.61 (each d, 1H, H-6, J6,5 = 8.0, 8.0 Hz), 7.14 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 7.6 Hz), 6.80 (d, 1H, H-6-mTyr, J6-mTyr,5-mTyr = 7.6 Hz), 6.74 (s, 1H, H-2-mTyr), 6.74 (d, 1H, H-4-mTyr, J4-mTyr,5-mTyr = 7.6 Hz), 6.38 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 6.9 Hz), 6.33 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 6.9 Hz), 6.26 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 6.24 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 5.94 (ddt, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 16.6, 10.9, 5.7 Hz), 5.86 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 5.80 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 5.31 (d, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 16.6 Hz), 5.28 (d, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 16.6 Hz), 5.18 (d, 1H, CH-Alloc, J = 10.9 Hz), 4.71 (d, 1H, H-α-DABA, JH-α-DABA,H-β-DABA = 8.0 Hz), 4.63 (d, 1H, H-α-DABA, JH-α-DABA,H-β-DABA = 10.3 Hz), 4.58–4.52 (m, 3H, H-3′-uridine, CH2-Alloc), 4.48–4.37 (m, 2H, H-2′-uridine, H-β-DABA), 4.41 (t, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 6.9 Hz), 4.35 (m, 1H, H-α-Met), 2.92 (d, 2H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 6.9 Hz), 2.81 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.80 (s, 3H, H-NCH3), 2.47 (m, 2H, H-γ-Met), 2.04 (s, 3H, SCH3-Met), 1.98 (dddd, 1H, H-β-Met, Jgem = Jβ-Met,α-Met = 14.2, Jβ-Met,γ-Met = 6.9, 2.3 Hz), 1.83 (ddd, 1H, H-β-Met, Jgem = Jβ-Met,α-Met = 14.2, Jβ-Met,γ-Met = 8.0 Hz), 1.39 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.29–1.24 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.21 (d, 3H, H-γ-DABA, JH-γ-DABA,H-β-DABA = 6.9 Hz), 1.10 (d, 18H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, J = 7.5 Hz), 0.92 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.88 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.15 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.12 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.08 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.01 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 125 MHz, 1:1 mixture of rotamers): δ 174.6, 173.0, 169.1, 168.9, 165.5, 159.4, 157.3, 152.3, 152.3, 144.1, 144.0, 142.1, 139.7, 134.3, 130.3, 123.5, 122.1, 119.0, 118.0, 117.6, 104.0, 101.3, 89.3, 82.8, 76.6, 76.3, 72.7, 67.6, 67.3, 56.7, 56.2, 54.6, 54.1, 39.4, 33.7, 30.9, 30.5, 28.3, 27.9, 26.3, 26.2, 19.0, 18.8, 18.5, 15.4, 14.5, 13.9, −3.9, −4.2, −4.3, −4.9; ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C58H100N7O13SSi3, 1218.64; found, 1218.7; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C58H100N7O13SSi3, 1218.6402; found, 1218.6417; [α]D23 +15.5 (c 0.89, CHCl3).

    Compound 18

    A solution of 17 (44.6 mg, 36.6 μmol) and morpholine (12.6 μL, 146.4 μmol) in THF (400 μL) was treated with Pd(PPh3)4 (21.1 mg, 18.3 μmol) at room temperature for 2 h. After SH silica gel was added to the mixture, the whole was stirred for 1 h. The SH silica gel was filtered off, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. A mixture of the crude amine, Boc-mTyr(TIPS)-OH (5) (32.0 mg, 73.2 μmol), and iPr2NEt (25.6 μL, 146.4 μmol) in DMF (400 μL) was treated with HATU (27.8 mg, 73.2 μmol) at room temperature for 5 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with AcOEt/hexane (4/1), which was washed with 0.1 M aq HCl, sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine. The organic layer was dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography (ϕ 1 × 10 cm, CHCl3/MeOH = 0–1–2–5%, then hexane/AcOEt = 50%) to afford 18 (24.8 mg, 16.0 μmol, 44%) as a colorless amorphous solid. 1H NMR (CD3OD, 500 MHz, 3:2 mixture of rotamers, selected data for the major rotamer): δ 7.38 (d, 1H, H-6-uridine, JH-6-uridine,H-5-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 7.18–7.11 (m, 2H, H-5-mTyr), 6.88 (d, 1H, H-4-mTyr, J4-mTyr,5-mTyr = 7.5 Hz), 6.83 (br s, 1H, H-2-mTyr), 6.81–6.68 (m, 4H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-6-mTyr), 6.49 (d, 1H, NH-mTyr, JNH-mTyr,α-mTyr = 8.6 Hz), 6.24 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 6.19 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 7.5 Hz), 5.73 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 4.91–4.84 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.71 (d, 1H, H-α-DABA, JH-α-DABA,H-β-DABA = 8.0 Hz), 4.68 (ddd, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 10.3, Jα-mTyr,NH-mTyr = 8.6, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 3.4 Hz), 4.49 (d, 1H, H-3′-uridine, JH-3′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 4.0 Hz), 4.42–4.47 (m, 2H, H-2′-uridine, H-α-mTyr), 4.37–4.30 (m, 1H, H-α-Met), 3.07 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.92 (d, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 6.9 Hz), 2.90–2.85 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr, H-β′-mTyr), 2.59 (dd, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jgem = 14.3, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 10.3 Hz), 2.51–2.45 (m, 2H, H-γ-Met), 2.05 (s, 3H, SCH3-Met), 2.02–1.95 (m, 1H, H-β-Met), 1.87–1.80 (m, 1H, H-β-Met), 1.39 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.34 (s, 9H, Boc-tBu), 1.31–1.20 (m, 9H, H-γ-DABA, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.12–1.10 (d, 36H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 0.90 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.85 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.12 (s, 3H, tBuCSi(CH3)2), 0.10 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.01 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.05 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); 13C NMR (CD3OD, 125 MHz, 1:1 mixture of rotamers): δ 174.8, 174.7, 174.4, 174.0, 173.1, 173.0, 168.7, 165.6, 165.5, 159.5, 159.4, 157.6, 157.5, 157.4, 157.3, 115.2, 143.9, 143.7, 142.5, 140.4, 139.7, 139.7, 139.4, 130.7, 130.5, 130.4, 123.6, 123.4, 123.2, 122.2, 122.1, 122.1, 104.0, 101.5, 101.4, 91.0, 82.8, 80.9, 80.5, 76.5, 75.9, 72.9, 72.6, 56.9, 56.6, 56.2, 56.1, 55.8, 54.3, 53.7, 53.0, 52.3, 40.3, 39.5, 39.3, 38.4, 33.5, 33.3, 31.0, 30.8, 28.9, 28.7, 28.6, 28.3, 26.4, 26.3, 26.2, 19.1, 18.8, 18.5, 18.5, 18.2, 18.5, 15.4, 14.3, 14.2, 13.9, 13.7, −3.8, −4.1, −4.2, −4.9, −4.9;     3′-hMRD A (2) and Sulfoxide Analogue 19

    A solution of 18 (17.0 mg, 10.9 μmol) in MeCN (1 mL) was treated with 3HF·Et3N (71.3 μL, 437.5 μmol) at room temperature for 50 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated, and the residue was diluted with AcOEt. The organic layer was washed with sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was treated with 80% aq TFA at room temperature for 2 h. After toluene was added, the mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was triturated with Et2O, and the precipitate was collected and purified by ODS column chromatography (H2O/MeCN = 0–30%, containing 0.1% TFA) to afford 3′-hMRD A (2) (4.2 mg, 4.9 μmol, 45% over two steps) and sulfoxide analogue 19 (3.3 mg, 3.8 μmol, 35% over two steps) as a white powder after lyophilization. 1H NMR (D2O, 500 MHz, 3:1 mixture of rotamers, selected data for the major rotamer): δ 7.30 (1H, H-5-mTyr, H-5′-mTyr, J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = J5′-mTyr,6′-mTyr = J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,4′-mTyr = 7.5 Hz), 7.22 (1H, H-5-mTyr, H-5′-mTyr, J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = J5′-mTyr,6′-mTyr = J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = J5-mTyr,4′-mTyr = 7.5 Hz), 7.10 (d, 1H, H-6-uridine, JH-6-uridine,H-5-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 6.87–6.73 (m, 6H, H-6-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-2-mTyr), 6.23 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 6.06 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 5.2 Hz), 5.65 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.0 Hz), 4.95 (dq, 1H, H-β-DABA, JH-β-DABA,H-α-DABA = 9.7, JH-β-DABA,H-γ-DABA = 6.9 Hz), 4.72 (d, 1H, H-3′-uridine, JH-3′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 5.2 Hz), 4.63 (d, 1H, H-α-DABA, JH-α-DABA,H-β-DABA = 9.2 Hz), 4.58 (dd, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 10.0, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 4.0 Hz), 4.36 (dd, 1H, H-α-mTyr, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 8.3, Jα-mTyr,β-mTyr = 5.7 Hz), 4.27 (dd, 1H, H-α-Met, JH-α-Met,H-β-Met = 8.0, JH-α-Met,H-β-Met = 5.7 Hz), 4.24 (dd, 1H, H-2′-uridine, JH-2′-uridine,H-3′-uridine = JH-2′-uridine,H-1′-uridine = 5.2 Hz), 3.06 (s, 3H, H-NCH3), 3.10–3.05 (m, 1H, H-β-mTyr), 3.02 (dd, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jgem = 14.3, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 5.7 Hz), 2.88 (dd, 1H, H-β-mTyr, Jgem = 14.2, Jβ-mTyr,α-mTyr = 8.3 Hz), 2.73–2.66 (m, 1H, H-β-mTyr), 2.55–2.42 (m, 2H, H-γ-Met), 2.06 (s, 3H, SCH3-Met), 2.00–1.95 (m, 2H, H-β-Met), 1.23 (d, 3H, H-γ-DABA, JH-γ-DABA,H-β-DABA = 6.9 Hz); ESIMS-LR m/z: 857.1 [(M + H)+]; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C38H49N8O13S, 857.3134; found, 857.3122; [α]D19 −13.4 (c 0.15, H2O). 1H NMR (D2O, 500 MHz, a mixture of diastereomers): δ 7.27 (1H, H-5-mTyr), 7.20 (1H, H-5-mTyr), 7.02 (m, 1H, H-6), 6.82–6.70 (m, 6H, H-6-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-2-mTyr), 6.19 (s, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 6.00 (m, 1H, H-1′-uridine), 5.58 (m, 1H, H-5-uridine), 4.91 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.72 (m, 1H, H-3′-uridine), 4.55 (m, 2H, H-α-DABA, H-α-mTyr), 4.38–4.15 (m, 3H, H-α-mTyr, H-α-Met, H-2′-uridine), 3.08–3.05 (m, 1H, H-β-mTyr), 3.05 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.94–2.80 (m, 4H, H-β-mTyr, H-γ-Met), 2.71–2.65 (m, 1H, H-β-mTyr), 2.65 (s, 3H, SOCH3-Met), 2.13–1.97 (m, 2H, H-β-Met), 1.18 (m, 3H, H-γ-DABA);     Compound 27

    A mixture of 15 (2.50 g, 3.1 mmol), (S)-2-[(fluorenylmethyl)amino]-3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)propanoic acid (26, 2.09 g, 4.0 mmol), and iPr2NEt (1.35 mL, 7.44 mol) in DMF (30 mL) was treated with HATU (981 mg, 1.56 mmol) at 0 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with AcOEt and washed with 0.1 M aq HCl, sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine. The organic layer was dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography (ϕ 5 × 15 cm, AcOEt/hexane = 33–55%) to afford 27 (3.59 g, 2.67 mol, 86%) as a colorless amorphous solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 9.07 (d, 1H, NH-5′-uridine, JNH-5′-uridine,H-5′-uridine = 10.1 Hz), 7.89–7.84 (m, 4H, H-Fmoc), 7.79–7.69 (m, 2H, H-6-uridine, NH-mTyr), 7.61 (t, 1H, H-Ph, JH-Ph,H-Phe = 8.5 Hz), 7.42–7.23 (m, 9H, H-Ph, H-Fmoc, NH-DABA), 7.14 (dd, 1H, H-5-mTyr, J5-mTyr,4-mTyr = 8.3 Hz, J5-mTyr,6-mTyr = 8.3 Hz), 6.91–6.84 (m, 2H, H-2-mTyr, H-6-mTyr), 6.69 (d, 1H, H-4-mTyr, J4-mTyr,5-mTyr = 8.3 Hz), 6.23 (d, 1H, H-1′-uridine, JH-1′-uridine,H-2′-uridine = 7.2 Hz), 6.20 (d, 1H, H-5′-uridine, JH-5′-uridine,NH-5′-uridine = 10.1 Hz), 5.87 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.7 Hz), 5.33 (m, 2H, H-NCH2OBn), 4.93–4.81 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.58–4.40 (m, 6H, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine, H-Fmoc, H-α-mTyr), 4.56 (s, 2H, H-CH2Ph), 4.25–4.17 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 2.98 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.71–2.62 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.34 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.26–1.14 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.07–0.97 (m, 21H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA), 0.86 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.76 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.01 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.11 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C72H104N6NaO13Si3, 1367.69; found, 1368.5; [α]D20 +17.4 (c 1.00, CHCl3).

    Compound 28

    A solution of 27 (2.63 g, 2.00 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (120 mL) was treated with 1 M BCl3 in CH2Cl2 (20 mL, 20 mmol) at −78 °C for 30 min and then at 0 °C for 15 min. After sat. aq NaHCO3 was added to the mixture, the resulting biphasic mixture was vigorously stirred for 15 min. The organic layer was separated and washed with sat. aq NaHCO3, H2O, and brine. The organic layer was dried (Na2SO4) and filtered. The residue was treated with a solution of HCl in AcOEt (4 M, 1.1 mL, 4.4 mmol) for 30 min. Hexane (200 mL) was added to the solution, which was concentrated in vacuo to one-third in volume. Hexane (100 mL) was added to the solution and was concentrated in vacuo. The precipitates were collected by filtration, washed with ether, and dried to afford 28 (1.31 g, quant.) as a pale brown solid. This compound was directly used in the next reaction without further purification. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 10.04 (s, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 7.87 (d, 2H, NH-DABA, JNH-DABA,H-α-DABA = 9.6 Hz), 7.67–6.37 (m, 13H, Fmoc, H-2, 4, 5, 6-mTyr, NH-DABA), 7.60 (m, 1H, NH-mTyr), 6.19 (m, 1H, H-1′-uridine), 5.20 (m, 1H, H-5-uridine), 4.92 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.57 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 4.10 (m, 7H, Fmoc, H-3′, 4′, 5′, H-α-mTyr), 2.95 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.66 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.24 (m, 3H, H-γ-DABA), 1.23–0.77 (m, 39H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.06 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.19 (m, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: 1125.6 [(M + Na)+]; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C59H89N6O10Si3, 1125.5942; found, 1125.5940; [α]D20 +8.6 (c 1.00, CHCl3).

    (S)-{[1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}glycine (29a)

    2-Chlorotrityl chloride resin (300 mg, 0.48 mmol) was placed in a 10 mL polypropylene syringe fitted with a polyethylene filter disc. The resin was washed with CH2Cl2 (2 mL), and a solution of Fmoc-Gly (428 mg, 1.4 mmol) and iPr2NEt (505 μL, 2.9 mmol) in CH2Cl2 was then added. After the mixture was agitated at room temperature for 2 h, the solvent and reagents were removed by suction. The resin bound to the Fmoc-amino acid was subjected to the following washing treatments with CH2Cl2/MeOH/iPr2NEt (17/2/1, 2 mL × 3), DMF (2 mL × 3), and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). The Fmoc group was removed with piperidine/DMF (1/4, 5 min, then 1/9, 15 min). The resin was washed with DMF (2 mL × 3) and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). A solution of 1,1′-carbonyldiimidazole (234 mg, 1.4 mmol) and N-methylmorpholine (319 μL, 2.9 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added to the resin. After the mixture was agitated at room temperature for 1 min, the solvent and reagents were removed by suction. This procedure was repeated 5 times. The resin was washed with CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). Then, a solution of l-Trp-OtBu·HCl (142 mg, 0.48 mmol) and iPr2NEt (251 μL, 1.4 mmol) in CH2Cl2 was added, and the mixture was agitated at room temperature for 3 h. The resin was washed with DMF (2 mL × 3) and CH2Cl2 (2 mL × 3). Completion of the reaction was confirmed by a Kaiser test. The resin was treated with 5% TFA/CH2Cl2 to cleave the urea-dipeptide, and the filtrate was partitioned between CH2Cl2 and H2O. The organic phase was washed with brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford 29a (43 mg, 0.11 mmol, 23%) as a white solid. This material was used for the next reaction without further purification. ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C18H23N3NaO5, 384.15; found, 383.7.

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-alanine (29b)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29b (123 mg, 0.33 mmol, 69%) was obtained as a white solid using l-Trp-OtBu·HCl (142 mg, 0.48 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C19H25N3NaO5, 398.17; found, 397.9.

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-leucine (29c)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29c (92 mg, 0.22 mmol, 46%) was obtained as a white solid using Fmoc-Leu (509 mg, 1.4 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C22H31N3NaO5, 440.22; found, 439.8.

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-isoleucine (29d)

    N-{[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-S-trityl-l-cysteine (29f)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29f (251 mg, 0.38 mmol, 80%) was obtained as a white solid using Fmoc-Cys(Trt) (843 mg, 1.4 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C38H39N3NaO5S, 672.25; found, 671.6.

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-methionine (29g)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29g (66 mg, 0.15 mmol, 63%) was obtained as a white solid using Fmoc-Met (267 mg, 0.72 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C21H29N3NaO5S, 458.17; found, 458.1.

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-phenyl-alanine (29h)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29h (72 mg, 0.16 mmol, 67%) was obtained as a white solid using Fmoc-Phe (279 mg, 0.72 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C25H29N3NaO5, 474.20; found, 474.1.

    (S)-2-{3-[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]ureido}-3-[4-(tert-butoxy)phenyl]propanoic Acid (29i)

    Nα-{[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-1-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-l-tryptophan (29j)

    Nα-{[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-N-trityl-l-histidine (29k)

    (S)-4-(tert-Butoxy)-2-{3-[(S)-1-(tert-butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]-ureido}-4-oxobutanoic Acid (29l)

    N2-{[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-Nω-[(2,2,4,6,7-pentamethyl-2,3-dihydrobenzofuran-5-yl)sulfonyl]-l-arginine (29o)

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 29a, 29o (133 mg, 0.19 mmol, 40%) was obtained as a white solid using Fmoc-Arg(Pbf) (934 mg, 1.4 mmol). ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C35H49N6O8S, 713.33; found, 713.0.

    N2-{[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-N5-trityl-l-glutamine (29s)

    {[(S)-1-(tert-Butoxy)-3-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-oxopropan-2-yl]carbamoyl}-l-proline (29t)

    A solution of l-Trp(Boc)·HCl (100 mg, 0.33 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (3.3 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of triphosgene (76 mg, 0.25 mmol) and Et3N (460 μL, 3.3 mmol) at −78 °C, and the mixture was stirred for 7 h. A solution of l-Pro-OH (37 mg, 0.66 mmol) in DMF (mL) was added to the mixture, which was stirred for 17 h. After H2O was added, the whole mixture was partitioned between AcOEt and 1 M aq HCl. The organic phase was washed with H2O and brine, dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel chromatography to afford 29t (20 mg, 0.05 mmol, 15%) as a white solid. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz): δ 10.82 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 7.53 (d, 1H, H-ε3-Trp, JH-ε3-Trp,H-ζ2-Trp = 9.0 Hz), 7.33 (d, 1H, H-ζ1-Trp, JH-ζ1-Trp,H-η-Trp = 8.1 Hz), 7.15 (s, 1H, H-δ1-Trp), 7.06 (dd, 1H, H-η-Trp, JH-η-Trp,H-ζ1-Trp = JH-η-Trp,H-ζ2-Trp = 8.1 Hz), 6.97 (dd, 1H, H-ζ2-Trp, JH-ζ2-Trp,H-η-Trp = 8.1, JH-ζ2-Trp,H-ε3-Trp = 9.0 Hz), 4.30–3.98 (m, 2H, H-α-Pro, H-α-Trp), 3.17–2.96 (m, 4H, H-β-Trp, H-δ-Pro), 1.93–1.74 (m, 4H, H-β-Pro, H-γ-Pro), 1.27 (s, 9H, tBu); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C21H27N3NaO5, 424.18; found, 424.0.

    Compound 30a

    A solution of 29a (68 mg, 0.10 mmol), 28 (56 mg, 0.05 mmol), and iPr2NEt (58 μL, 0.33 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) was treated with HBTU (42 mg, 0.11 mmol) at room temperature for 2 h. The mixture was partitioned between AcOEt and 1 M aq HCl and brine. The organic phase was dried (Na2SO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography to afford 30a (16 mg, 0.01 mmol, 10%) as a pale yellow syrup. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 11.41 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.76 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.40–9.31 (m, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 8.17–8.04 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.90–7.79 (m, 2H, H-Fmoc), 7.71–7.45 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr, H-ε3-Trp), 7.43–7.20 (m, 5H, H-Fmoc, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp), 7.19–6.60 (m, 6H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.42 (d, 1H, NH-α-Trp, JNH-α-Trp,H-α-Trp = 8.1 Hz), 6.42–6.29 (m, 1H, NH-Gly), 6.22–6.08 (m, 2H, H-1′-uridine, H-5′-uridine), 5.67 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 8.2 Hz), 5.06–4.71 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.68–4.58 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 4.57–4.02 (m, 7H, H-Fmoc, H-α-Trp, H-α-mTyr, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.68 (br s, 2H, H-α-Gly), 3.08–2.84 (m, 2H, H-β-Trp), 3.02 (s, 3H, NCH3), 2.81–2.58 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.27 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.31–1.14 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.07–0.97 (m, 21H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA), 0.86 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.80 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.01 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.10 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C77H109N9NaO14Si3, 1492.73; found, 1490.8; [α]D20 −2.0 (c 1.00, MeOH).

    Compound 30b

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 30a, 30b (28 mg, 0.018 mmol, 38%) was obtained as a pale yellow syrup using 29b (20 mg, 0.05 mmol). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 11.44 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.77 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.02 (d, 1H, NH-5′-uridine, JNH-5-uridine,H-5′-uridine = 8.7 Hz), 8.02 (d, 1H, NH-DABA, JNH-DABA,H-α-DABA = 9.6 Hz), 7.90–7.80 (m, 2H, H-Fmoc), 7.71–7.45 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr, H-ε3-Trp), 7.43–7.20 (m, 5H, H-Fmoc, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp), 7.20–6.62 (m, 6H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.39 (d, 1H, NH-Ala, JNH-Ala,H-α-Ala = 6.7 Hz), 6.27 (d, 1H, NH-Trp, JNH-Trp,α-Trp = 7.6 Hz), 6.22–6.05 (m, 2H, H-1′-uridine, H-5′-uridine), 5.64 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 7.6 Hz), 4.64–4.05 (m, 9H, H-Fmoc, H-α-DABA, H-α-Ala, H-α-Trp, H-α-mTyr, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.08–2.92 (m, 5H, H-β-Trp, NCH3), 2.80–2.58 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.28 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.32–1.14 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.12 (d, 3H, H-β-Ala, JH-β-Ala,H-α-Ala = 6.7 Hz), 1.07–0.94 (m, 21H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA), 0.86 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.80 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.00 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.08 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C78H111N9NaO14Si3, 1504.75; found, 1504.8; [α]D20 −2.6 (c 1.00, MeOH).

    Compound 30c

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 30a, 30c (26 mg, 0.017 mmol, 17%) was obtained as a pale yellow syrup using 29c (42 mg, 0.10 mmol). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 11.39 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.76 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.21–9.08 (m, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 8.30–8.24 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.90–7.79 (m, 2H, H-Fmoc), 7.70–7.47 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr, H-ε3-Trp), 7.47–7.19 (m, 5H, H-Fmoc, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp), 7.19–6.59 (m, 6H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.38–6.30 (m, 1H, NH-α-Trp), 6.25–6.04 (m, 2H, H-1′-uridine, H-5′-uridine, NH-Leu), 5.66–5.58 (m, 1H, H-5-uridine), 5.06–4.85 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.57–4.02 (m, 8H, H-α-DABA, H-Fmoc, H-α-Trp, H-α-mTyr, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.08–2.84 (m, 5H, H-β-Trp, NCH3), 2.79–2.60 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.71–1.12 (m, 6H, H-β-Leu, H-γ-Leu, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.27 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.01–0.92 (m, 21H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA), 0.92–0.66 (m, 24H, SiC(CH3)3, H-δ-Leu), 0.80 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.01 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.08 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C81H117N9NaO14Si3, 1546.79; found, 1547.8; [α]D20 −6.5 (c 1.00, MeOH).

    Compound 30d

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 30a, 30d (27 mg, 0.017 mmol, 18%) was obtained as a pale yellow syrup using 29d (42 mg, 0.10 mmol). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 10.75 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.09–9.02 (m, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 8.37–8.25 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.91–7.78 (m, 2H, H-Fmoc), 7.71–7.46 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr, H-ε3-Trp), 7.44–7.22 (m, 5H, H-Fmoc, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp), 7.20–6.62 (m, 6H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.38–6.28 (m, 1H, NH-Ile), 6.28–6.07 (m, 3H, NH-α-Trp, H-1′-uridine, H-5′-uridine), 5.67–5.57 (m, 1H, H-5-uridine), 5.91–4.87 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.63–3.94 (m, 9H, H-α-DABA, H-Fmoc, H-α-Trp, H-α-mTyr, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine, H-α-Ile), 3.06–2.84 (m, 5H, H-β-Trp, NCH3), 2.77–2.60 (m, 2H, H-β-mTyr), 1.68–1.52 (m, 1H, H-β-Ile), 1.68–1.52 (m, 1H, H-γ-Ile), 1.51–1.33 (m, 1H, H-γ-Ile), 1.32–1.14 (m, 7H, H-γ-Ile, H-δ-Ile, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.27 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.07–0.97 (m, 24H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA, H-β-Me-Ile), 0.88–0.71 (m, 21H, H-γ-Me-Ile, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.03 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.01 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.08 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C81H118N9O14Si3, 1524.81; found, 1525.0; [α]D20 −10.7 (c 1.00, MeOH).

    Compound 30e

    Compound 30s

    Compound 30t

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 30a, 30t (40 mg, 0.026 mmol, 53%) was obtained as a pale yellow syrup using 29t (20 mg, 0.05 mmol). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C): δ 11.44 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.73 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.06–8.93 (m, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 8.23–8.14 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.90–7.81 (m, 2H, H-Fmoc), 7.67–7.47 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr, H-ε3-Trp), 7.43–7.21 (m, 5H, H-Fmoc, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp), 7.17–6.62 (m, 6H, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.22–6.11 (m, 2H, H-1′-uridine, H-5′-uridine), 5.97–5.88 (m, 1H, NH-α-Trp), 5.67 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 7.2 Hz), 4.98–4.86 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.58–4.05 (m, 9H, H-α-DABA, H-Fmoc, H-α-Pro, H-α-Trp, H-α-mTyr, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.14–2.57 (m, 9H, H-β-Trp, H-δ-Pro, H-β-mTyr, NCH3), 1.98–1.70 (m, 4H, H-β-Pro, H-γ-Pro), 1.29 (s, 9H, tBu), 1.31–1.15 (m, 3H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3), 1.07–0.98 (m, 21H, Si[CH(CH3)2]3, H-γ-DABA), 0.86 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.80 (s, 9H, SiC(CH3)3), 0.07 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.04 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), 0.00 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2), −0.09 (s, 3H, tBuSi(CH3)2); ESIMS-LR m/z: calcd for C80H113N9NaO14Si3, 1530.76; found, 1530.5; [α]D20 −22.7 (c 1.00, MeOH).

    Compound 25a

    A solution of 30a (10 mg, 6.8 μmol) in MeCN (136 μL) was treated with 3HF·Et3N (44 μL, 270 mmol) at room temperature for 3 d. Trimethylsilanol (70 μL, 630 μmol) was added to the reaction mixture, which was further stirred for 1 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was treated with 20% Et2NH/MeCN (250 μL) at room temperature for 1 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was triturated with Et2O. The solvent was removed by decantation, and the resulting precipitate was treated with 80% aq TFA (250 μL) at room temperature for 3 h. After toluene was added, the mixture was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was triturate with Et2O and the solvent was removed by decantation. The precipitate was purified by ODS column chromatography (MeCN/H2O = 10–30%, containing 0.1% TFA) to afford 25a (1.5 mg, 1.6 μmol, 24% over three steps) as a yellow powder. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C, 3:2 mixture of rotamers, selected data for the major rotamer): δ 11.37 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.77 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Tr), 9.58–9.44 (m, 1H, NH-5′-uridine), 9.45–9.26 (m, 2H, NH-mTyr), 8.63–8.54 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.62 (d, 1H, H-ε3-Trp, JH-ε3-Trp,H-ζ2-Trp = 7.8 Hz), 7.42–6.71 (m, 9H, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.47–6.32 (m, 2H, NH-Gly, NH-α-Trp), 6.17–6.01 (m, 1H, H-1′-uridine), 5.74–5.64 (m, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 5.47 (d, 1H, H-5-uridine, JH-5-uridine,H-6-uridine = 7.8 Hz), 4.97–4.84 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.76–4.56 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 4.46–4.27 (m, 2H, H-α-Tyr, H-α-Trp), 4.41–3.91 (m, 2H, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.74–3.63 (m, 2H, H-α-Gly), 3.17–2.79 (m, 4H, H-β-Trp, H-β-mTyr), 2.90 (s, 3H, NCH3), 1.22–1.15 (m, 3H, H-γ-DABA); ESIMS-LR m/z: 806.3 [(M + H)+]; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C37H44N9O12, 806.3104; found, 806.3048; [α]D20 +3.4 (c 0.12, MeOH).

    Compound 25b

    In a manner similar to the synthesis of 25a, 25b (0.5 mg, 0.5 μmol, 7.4% over three steps) was obtained as a pale yellow powder using 30b (10 mg, 6.7 μmol). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 400 MHz, T = 50 °C, 3:2 mixture of rotamers, selected data for the major rotamer): δ 11.34 (s, 1H, H-N3-uridine), 10.77 (s, 1H, NH-δ1-Trp), 9.43–9.30 (m, 2H, NH-5′-uridine, NH-mTyr), 8.29–8.18 (m, 1H, DABA-NH), 7.55–7.47 (m, 1H, H-ε3-Trp), 7.37–6.56 (m, 9H, H-6-uridine, H-ζ1-Trp, H-η-Trp, H-2-mTyr, H-4-mTyr, H-5-mTyr, H-6-mTyr, H-δ1-Trp, H-ζ2-Trp), 6.47–6.36 (m, 1H, NH-Ala), 6.26–6.16 (m, 1H, NH-α-Trp), 6.15–6.04 (m, 1H, H-1′-uridine), 5.59–5.46 (m, 1H, H-5′-uridine), 5.39–5.32 (m, 1H, H-5-uridine), 4.98–4.88 (m, 1H, H-β-DABA), 4.81–4.67 (m, 1H, H-α-DABA), 4.66–4.28 (m, 2H, H-α-mTyr, H-α-Trp), 4.22–3.87 (m, 3H, H-α-Ala, H-2′-uridine, H-3′-uridine), 3.13–2.78 (m, 7H, H-β-Trp, H-β-mTyr, NCH3), 1.33–1.00 (m, 6H, H-γ-DABA, H-β-Ala); ESIMS-LR m/z: 820.4 [(M + H)+]; ESIMS-HR m/z: calcd for C38H46N9O12, 820.3260; found, 820.3256; [α]D20 −1.7 (c 0.02, MeOH).

    Compound 25c
